description: North Korean state-sponsored group known for financial cybercrime, destructive attacks, and espionage operations including the Sony Pictures hack, WannaCry ransomware, and numerous cryptocurrency thefts.

tools.name: WannaCry
tools.description: WannaCry is a ransomware program that encrypts files on infected computers and asks users to pay ransom in Bitcoin to decrypt them. It spread through an exploit in Windows SMBv1 and caused massive disruption to businesses and critical infrastructure worldwide.

tools.name: ThreatNeedle
tools.description: ThreatNeedle is a backdoor that has been used by Lazarus Group since at least 2019 to target cryptocurrency, defense, and mobile gaming organizations. It is considered to be an advanced cluster of Lazarus Group's Manuscrypt (a.k.a. NukeSped) malware family.

tools.name: Dtrack
tools.description: Dtrack is spyware that was discovered in 2019 and has been used against Indian financial institutions, research facilities, and the Kudankulam Nuclear Power Plant. Dtrack shares similarities with the DarkSeoul campaign, which was attributed to Lazarus Group.

tools.name: RATANKBA
tools.description: RATANKBA is a remote controller tool used by Lazarus Group. RATANKBA has been used in attacks targeting financial institutions in Poland, Mexico, Uruguay, the United Kingdom, and Chile. It was also seen used against organizations related to telecommunications, management consulting, information technology, insurance, aviation, and education. RATANKBA has a graphical user interface to allow the attacker to issue jobs to perform on the infected machines.

notes.text: We named Lazarus the most active group of 2020
notes.author: Kaspersky ICS CERT

description: North Korean subgroup of Lazarus Group that primarily targets South Korean organizations, particularly in healthcare, government, and financial sectors.

sources.note: Initial identification by South Korean security firm

tools.name: gh0st RAT
tools.description: Gh0st RAT (Remote Access Terminal) is a trojan “Remote Access Tool” used on Windows platforms, and has been used to hack into some of the most sensitive computer networks on Earth.

notes.text: Focuses heavily on South Korean government agencies, military organizations, and a variety of domestic companies
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: North Korean subgroup of Lazarus Group specializing in financial institutions and cryptocurrency theft operations.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post‑exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, PINs and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems (LSASS memory, SAM, etc.), enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: DarkComet
tools.description: DarkComet is a remote access tool (RAT) with features including remote shell, file transfer, keylogging, screen and video capture, and remote process control — commonly used to control compromised hosts and collect sensitive data.

tools.name: Net (Windows)
tools.description: The Net utility is a component of the Windows operating system. It is used in command-line operations for control of users, groups, services, and network connections. Net has a great deal of functionality, much of which is useful for an adversary, such as gathering system and network information for Discovery, moving laterally through SMB/Windows Admin Shares using net use commands, and interacting with services.

notes.text: Significant operations include the 2016 Bank of Bangladesh heist, during which APT38 stole $81 million, as well as attacks against Bancomext and Banco de Chile
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Chinese military unit conducting cyber espionage operations primarily targeting intellectual property and sensitive information from various industries.

sources.note: Groundbreaking 2013 report that first publicly attributed this group

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post‑exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, PINs and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems (LSASS memory, SAM, etc.), enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: PoisonIvy
tools.description: PoisonIvy is a remote access trojan (RAT) providing remote shell, file transfer, keylogging, screen capture, and persistence mechanisms; commonly used for interactive control and data exfiltration.

tools.name: PsExec
tools.description: PsExec is a Windows Sysinternals utility used to execute processes on remote systems. Adversaries use it for lateral movement, remote command execution, and service/agent deployment in compromised networks.

notes.text: First APT group to be publicly attributed to specific PLA unit
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Russian military intelligence cyber unit targeting government, military, and security organizations worldwide. This group has been active since at least 2004.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post‑exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, PINs and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems (LSASS memory, SAM, etc.), enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: Responder
tools.description: Responder is an open source tool used for LLMNR, NBT-NS and MDNS poisoning, with built-in HTTP/SMB/MSSQL/FTP/LDAP rogue authentication server supporting NTLMv1/NTLMv2/LMv2, Extended Security NTLMSSP and Basic HTTP authentication.

tools.name: certutil
tools.description: CertUtil.exe is an admin command line tool intended by Microsoft to be used for manipulating certification authority (CA) data and components. This includes verifying certificates and certificate chains, dumping and displaying CA configuration information and configuring Certificate Services. Attackers can use certutil to replace PowerShell for specific tasks such as downloading a file from a remote URL and encoding and decoding a Base64 obfuscated payload.

notes.text: APT28 reportedly compromised the Hillary Clinton campaign, the Democratic National Committee, and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee in 2016 in an attempt to interfere with the U.S. presidential election.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Financially motivated group targeting banks, payment processors, and hospitality companies worldwide. Often confused with separate Carbanak group.

tools.name: AdFind
tools.description: AdFind is a command-line Active Directory query tool that plays a significant role in the ransomware ecosystem, particularly in the reconnaissance phase of a ransomware attack chain. Originally designed for legitimate administrative purposes, AdFind is often leveraged by threat actors to gather critical information about an organization's Active Directory environment. This information is crucial for understanding the network topology, identifying high-value targets, and planning subsequent stages of the attack.

tools.name: Cobalt Strike
tools.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as 'adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors'. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.

tools.name: Carbanak
tools.description: Carbanak is a remote backdoor designed for espionage, data exfiltration, and to remote control.

notes.text: FIN7 may be linked to the Carbanak Group, but there appears to be several groups using Carbanak malware and are therefore tracked separately.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Turla is a Russian state-sponsored cyber espionage group attributed to the FSB. Active since at least 2004, Turla has targeted government, military, educational, and research organizations across more than 50 countries. Known for sophisticated malware, watering hole attacks, and stealthy persistence mechanisms.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history
Detailed analysis of Turla's Epic campaign
US government advisory on Snake malware

tools.name: Kazuar
tools.description: Kazuar is a .NET-based backdoor that supports encrypted command-and-control communications, keylogging, remote shell access, and data exfiltration. It is designed for long-term espionage and stealthy persistence across Windows systems.

tools.name: Snake
tools.description: Snake (also known as Uroburos) is a sophisticated rootkit and cyber espionage platform capable of covert data exfiltration, modular payload delivery, and long-term persistence. It supports multiple operating systems including Windows, Linux, and macOS.

tools.name: Carbon
tools.description: Carbon is a second-stage backdoor designed for lateral movement and remote command execution. It communicates over HTTPS and includes features for system reconnaissance, payload delivery, and command scheduling.

tools.name: PowerShell
tools.description: PowerShell is a Windows command-line shell and scripting language used for system administration, automation, and remote execution. It is often leveraged by threat actors for in-memory execution and obfuscation.

notes.text: Turla is known for using watering hole attacks and custom backdoors to compromise military and government targets across more than 50 countries.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: APT32 is a Vietnam-based cyber espionage group active since at least 2014. It targets foreign governments, dissidents, journalists, and private sector industries across Southeast Asia. Known for strategic web compromises, phishing, and custom malware.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history
Targeting of corporate media and private sector

tools.name: Cobalt Strike
tools.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial adversary simulation tool that provides post-exploitation capabilities including command execution, lateral movement, and beaconing.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post-exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems, enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: PowerShell
tools.description: PowerShell is a Windows command-line shell and scripting language used for system administration, automation, and remote execution. It is often leveraged by threat actors for in-memory execution and obfuscation.

notes.text: APT32 has used Cobalt Strike and Mimikatz during large-scale operations targeting Southeast Asian governments and private sector organizations.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: Sidewinder is a cyber espionage group active since at least 2012, suspected to be Indian. It has targeted government, military, and business entities across South Asia, including Pakistan, China, Nepal, and Afghanistan. Known for spear-phishing, malware loaders, and registry-based persistence.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history

tools.name: PowerShell
tools.description: PowerShell is a Windows command-line shell and scripting language used for system administration, automation, and remote execution. It is often leveraged by threat actors for in-memory execution and obfuscation.

tools.name: MSHTA
tools.description: MSHTA is a Windows utility used to execute Microsoft HTML Applications (HTA). It can be leveraged by threat actors to run malicious scripts and bypass application control mechanisms.

tools.name: JavaScript
tools.description: JavaScript is a scripting language commonly used in web environments to create interactive content and automate browser-side behaviour. Threat actors may use it to deliver malicious payloads, redirect users, or exploit vulnerabilities in client-side applications.

notes.text: Sidewinder has used PowerShell, MSHTA, and JavaScript to drop and execute malware loaders, often delivered via spear-phishing campaigns targeting South Asian government and military organisations.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: Patchwork is a suspected Indian cyber espionage group active since at least 2015. It has targeted diplomatic, government, and think tank organisations across South and Southeast Asia, often using spear-phishing and custom malware loaders.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history

tools.name: PowerSploit
tools.description: PowerSploit is a modular post-exploitation framework written in PowerShell. It includes scripts for code execution, credential theft, and reconnaissance.

tools.name: QuasarRAT
tools.description: QuasarRAT is a remote access trojan written in .NET that provides keylogging, screen capture, file manipulation, and remote command execution. It is commonly used by threat actors for surveillance and data exfiltration.

tools.name: AutoIt
tools.description: AutoIt is a scripting language designed for automating the Windows GUI and general scripting. It can be compiled into standalone executables and is used by threat actors to deliver and execute payloads.

notes.text: Patchwork has used PowerSploit, QuasarRAT, and AutoIt-based backdoors in spear-phishing campaigns targeting diplomatic and government organisations across South Asia.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: APT34 is a suspected Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group active since at least 2014. It has targeted government, energy, financial, and telecommunications organisations across the Middle East and beyond, using spear-phishing, credential theft, and custom web shells.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history
Toolset and targeting overview, including 2019 leaks

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post-exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems, enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: LaZagne
tools.description: LaZagne is an open-source credential recovery tool that extracts passwords from local applications. It supports modules for browsers, databases, and system components, and has been used by threat actors to gather credentials from compromised systems.

tools.name: CertUtil
tools.description: CertUtil is a Windows command-line utility for managing certificates and certificate services. Threat actors use it to download remote payloads, encode and decode data, and bypass security controls.

notes.text: APT34 has used LaZagne, CertUtil, and Mimikatz to maintain access and extract credentials from government and energy sector targets across the Middle East.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: MuddyWater is an Iranian state-sponsored cyber espionage group active since at least 2017. It has targeted government, telecommunications, and private organisations across the Middle East, Europe, North America, and Asia, using PowerShell-based backdoors, DNS tunneling, and credential theft.

sources.note: Primary technical profile and campaign history
Joint advisory on MuddyWater operations and toolset
Infrastructure and malware analysis of MuddyWater operations

tools.name: PowerShell
tools.description: PowerShell is a Windows command-line shell and scripting language used for system administration, automation, and remote execution. It is often leveraged by threat actors for in-memory execution and obfuscation.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post-exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems, enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

notes.text: MuddyWater has used PowerShell-based backdoors, DNS tunneling, and credential theft tools like Mimikatz to compromise government and telecom targets across the Middle East, North America, Asia, and Europe.
notes.author: Analyst Águeda Alemany

description: Israeli military intelligence unit responsible for the Stuxnet operation targeting Iranian nuclear facilities. Stuxnet is typically introduced to the target environment via an infected USB flash drive.

tools.name: Stuxnet
tools.description: Sophisticated malware designed to target and sabotage industrial control systems, specifically Siemens PLCs at Iranian nuclear facilities. Uses zero-day exploits and USB propagation.

description: A threat actor using Duqu 2.0 targeted individuals and companies linked to the P5+1 (the five permanent member states of the UN Security Council, plus Germany) conducting negotiations on Iran's nuclear program. Might be related to Stuxnet and attributed to Israel.

sources.note: Targeting of Iran nuclear negotiation hotels

tools.name: Duqu 2.0
tools.description: Advanced espionage malware targeting diplomatic negotiations, operates primarily in-memory with minimal disk footprint, making detection difficult.

description: Might be related to Duqu and Stuxnet and attributed to Israel. Potentially represents the broader Israeli cyber operations umbrella.

sources.note: Analysis suggesting connection to Stuxnet origins
Detection rules for Cheshire Cat malware

description: Private Israeli disinformation-for-hire group conducting influence operations and social media manipulation campaigns for clients worldwide.

sources.note: Investigation into Team Jorge disinformation operations

description: Israeli threat actor with limited public information available.
Collaborative umbrella of various threat actors involved in Olympic Games / Stuxnet operations. Represents coordination between multiple advanced threat groups.

tools.name: Flame
tools.description: Sophisticated cyber espionage malware used for targeted attacks and data collection.

tools.name: Stuxnet
tools.description: Advanced malware targeting industrial control systems.

tools.name: Miniflame
tools.description: Smaller variant of Flame malware.

tools.name: Duqu
tools.description: Information-stealing malware related to Stuxnet.

tools.name: Gauss
tools.description: Banking trojan targeting Middle Eastern financial systems.

description: Probably the most sophisticated computer attack group in the world, attributed to NSA's Tailored Access Operations (TAO) unit. Active since 2001. Kaspersky documented 500+ infections across 42+ countries (likely tens of thousands total). Uses virtual file systems, registry-based persistence, iPhone/Mac exploits, 300+ domains, 100+ servers for C&C. Capable of bridging air-gapped networks via USB. Bypasses code-signing with exploited signed drivers. Rivals Stuxnet/Flame in technical sophistication. Arsenal stolen by Shadow Brokers in 2016, leading to WannaCry and NotPetya outbreaks. Part of Five Eyes (NSA, GCHQ, CSIS, ASIS, GCSB).

sources.note: Comprehensive analysis of 14 years of operations
Inside look at NSA Equation Group operations

tools.name: Regin
tools.description: Highly sophisticated modular malware platform for long-term intelligence gathering and GSM network compromise.

tools.name: EquationLaser
tools.description: Advanced persistent threat tool from the Equation Group arsenal.

tools.name: EquationDrug
tools.description: Sophisticated malware platform with extensive modular capabilities.

tools.name: DoubleFantasy
tools.description: Validator and intelligence gathering tool used in targeted operations.

tools.name: TripleFantasy
tools.description: Advanced backdoor with extensive data collection capabilities.

tools.name: Fanny
tools.description: USB worm used to bridge air-gapped networks, predates Stuxnet.

tools.name: Grayfish
tools.description: Advanced bootkit capable of surviving OS reinstallation by infecting firmware.

tools.name: DanderSpritz
tools.description: Post-exploitation framework leaked by Shadow Brokers.

tools.name: DoublePulsar
tools.description: Kernel-mode backdoor implant leaked by Shadow Brokers, used in WannaCry.

tools.name: ETERNALBLUE
tools.description: SMB exploit leaked by Shadow Brokers, used in WannaCry and NotPetya ransomware.

tools.name: ETERNALROMANCE
tools.description: SMB exploit leaked by Shadow Brokers.

tools.name: Bvp47
tools.description: Top-tier backdoor used by Equation Group for long-term access.

description: CIA subgroup active since at least 2009. Exposed through Vault 7/8 WikiLeaks. Has infected 40 targets in 16+ countries across Middle East, Europe, Asia, and Africa. Uses sophisticated espionage malware with high operational security - detailed fingerprinting, discovery, and exfiltration capabilities. Communicates with C&C over HTTPS using custom cryptography, per-target domain/IP configurations, and randomized intervals to evade detection. Targets aerospace, telecoms, energy, financial, government, and IT sectors.

sources.note: Chinese security firm attribution to CIA

tools.name: Black Lambert
tools.description: Component of the Lambert malware family.

tools.name: Blue Lambert
tools.description: Component of the Lambert malware family.

tools.name: Gray Lambert
tools.description: Component of the Lambert malware family.

tools.name: Green Lambert
tools.description: Component of the Lambert malware family.

tools.name: Pink Lambert
tools.description: Component of the Lambert malware family.

tools.name: White Lambert
tools.description: Component of the Lambert malware family.

description: French intelligence agency cyber espionage operation discovered by CSEC in 2009. Active since at least 2011. CSEC assesses with moderate certainty this is a state-sponsored CNO (Cyber Network Operation) effort by French intelligence. Consists of three implants: two 'snowballs' and one sophisticated 'snowman' discovered in mid-2010. Known for Animal Farm suite of malware with animal-themed names. Targets government, defense, media, and diplomatic entities across Europe, Middle East, Africa, and Asia.

sources.note: Analysis of Animal Farm malware suite
Animal Farm APT and French intelligence attribution
Technical analysis of Dino spying malware

tools.name: Babar
tools.description: Sophisticated espionage malware with extensive data collection capabilities.

tools.name: Bunny
tools.description: Lua-instrumented malware component of Animal Farm suite.

tools.name: Dino
tools.description: Component of the Animal Farm malware suite.

tools.name: Casper
tools.description: Component of the Animal Farm malware suite.

tools.name: Tafacalou
tools.description: Component of the Animal Farm malware suite.

tools.name: NBot
tools.description: Component of the Animal Farm malware suite.

tools.name: Chocopop
tools.description: Component of the Animal Farm malware suite.

description: Highly sophisticated APT platform rivaling Project Sauron and Regin in complexity. Active since at least 2012, attributed to US Joint Special Operations Command (JSOC) and Five Eyes. Infection vector via compromised MikroTik routers - malicious component downloaded by Winbox Loader (router management suite) infects administrators. Uses virtual file systems and advanced operational security. Targets entities across Middle East and Africa including Afghanistan, Congo, Iraq, Jordan, Kenya, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Tanzania, Turkey, Yemen.

sources.note: Attribution to US SOCOM and Five Eyes

tools.name: Slingshot
tools.description: Full-blown spying framework with kernel-mode and user-mode components.

tools.name: Cahnadr
tools.description: Kernel-mode component of Slingshot framework.

tools.name: GollumApp
tools.description: User-mode component of Slingshot framework.

description: Highly sophisticated APT framework consisting of two packages named 'Tokyo' and 'Yokohama'. Known to have targeted a single victim - a diplomatic entity from a country in Central Asia. Attribution unknown.

sources.note: Discovery and technical analysis of Tajmahal framework

tools.name: Tokyo
tools.description: First package of the Tajmahal spying framework.

tools.name: Yokohama
tools.description: Second package of the Tajmahal spying framework.

description: Turkish state-sponsored APT conducting DNS hijacking campaigns since at least January 2017. Cisco Talos identified 40+ organizations compromised across 13 countries. Focused on illicitly modifying DNS records to redirect users to actor-controlled servers, enabling traffic interception and obtaining valid encryption certificates. Targets include ministries of foreign affairs, military organizations, intelligence agencies, energy organizations, NGOs, think tanks, telecommunications, and aerospace/defense sectors across Middle East, North Africa, and Europe. DHS issued alert Jan 2019 warning about this activity.

sources.note: Initial discovery and analysis of Sea Turtle campaign
PwC analysis calling group Teal Kurma

tools.name: DNS Hijacking
tools.description: Man-in-the-middle attacks via DNS record manipulation to redirect traffic and steal credentials.

description: APT29 is threat group that has been attributed to Russia's Foreign Intelligence Service (SVR). They have operated since at least 2008, often targeting government networks in Europe and NATO member countries, research institutes, and think tanks. APT29 reportedly compromised the Democratic National Committee starting in the summer of 2015.

tools.name: SUNBURST
tools.description: SUNBURST is a trojanized DLL designed to fit within the SolarWinds Orion software update framework. It was used by APT29 since at least February 2020.

tools.name: GoldMax
tools.description: Gold Max is a Golang written command and control backdoor used by the NOBELIUM threat actor group. It uses several different techniques to obfuscate its actions and evade detection. The malware writes an encrypted configuration file to disk, where the file name and AES-256 cipher keys are unique per implant and based on environmental variables and information about the network where it is running.

tools.name: GoldFinder
tools.description: Another tool written in Go, GoldFinder was most likely used as a custom HTTP tracer tool that logs the route or hops that a packet takes to reach a hardcoded C2 server. When launched, the malware issues an HTTP request for a hardcoded IP address (e.g., hxxps://185[.]225[.]69[.]69/) and logs the HTTP response to a plaintext log file (e.g., loglog.txt created in the present working directory).

tools.name: Sibot
tools.description: Sibot is dual-purpose malware written in VBScript designed to achieve persistence on a compromised system as well as download and execute additional payloads. Microsoft discovered three Sibot variants in early 2021 during its investigation of APT29 and the SolarWinds Compromise.

notes.text: The Dukes show unusual confidence in their ability to continue successfully compromising their targets, as well as in their ability to operate with impunity.
notes.author: malpedia

description: menuPass is a threat group that has been active since at least 2006. Individual members of menuPass are known to have acted in association with the Chinese Ministry of State Security's (MSS) Tianjin State Security Bureau and worked for the Huaying Haitai Science and Technology Development Company.

tools.name: QuasarRAT
tools.description: Quasar RAT is a malware family written in .NET which is used by a variety of attackers. The malware is fully functional and open source, and is often packed to make analysis of the source more difficult.

tools.name: PsExec
tools.description: PsExec is a free Microsoft tool that can be used to execute a program on another computer. It is used by IT administrators and attackers.

tools.name: RedLeaves
tools.description: RedLeaves is a malware family used by menuPass. The code overlaps with PlugX and may be based upon the open source tool Trochilus.

tools.name: Cobalt Strike
tools.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as 'adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors'. Cobalt Strike’s interactive post-exploit capabilities cover the full range of ATT&CK tactics, all executed within a single, integrated system.

notes.text: APT10 knows no boundaries when it comes to attacks. For example, one of the group's most notable campaigns was in 2014 when it targeted the US Office of Personnel Management (OPM) and stole the personal information of over 21 million government employees. This was considered one of the largest breaches of federal government data in US history.
notes.author: forbes

description: APT41 is a threat group that researchers have assessed as Chinese state-sponsored espionage group that also conducts financially-motivated operations. Active since at least 2012.

tools.name: ShadowPad
tools.description: The ShadowPad advanced modular remote access trojan (RAT) has been deployed by the Chinese government-sponsored BRONZE ATLAS threat group since at least 2017. A growing list of other Chinese threat groups have deployed it globally since 2019 in attacks against organizations in various industry verticals.

tools.name: PlugX
tools.description: RSA describes PlugX as a RAT (Remote Access Trojan) malware family that is around since 2008 and is used as a backdoor to control the victim's machine fully. Once the device is infected, an attacker can remotely execute several kinds of commands on the affected system.

tools.name: DUSTPAN
tools.description: DUSTPAN is an in-memory dropper written in C/C++ used by APT41 since 2021 that decrypts and executes an embedded payload.

notes.text: APT41's modus operandi is to perform cyber espionage, espionage and financial gain activities benefiting the nation state.
notes.author: fortiguard

description: FIN6 is a cyber crime group that has stolen payment card data and sold it for profit on underground marketplaces. This group has aggressively targeted and compromised point of sale (PoS) systems in the hospitality and retail sectors.

tools.name: FrameworkPOS
tools.description: FrameworkPOS is a point of sale (POS) malware used by FIN6 to steal payment card data from sytems that run physical POS devices.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a credential-dumping utility commonly leveraged by adversaries, penetration testers, and red teams to extract passwords. As an open source project, Mimikatz continues to be actively developed.

tools.name: PsExec
tools.description: PsExec is a free Microsoft tool that can be used to execute a program on another computer. It is used by IT administrators and attackers.

notes.text: Cybercriminals from the long-running FIN6 group are posing as job seekers on platforms like LinkedIn to infect recruiters with malware delivered through fake resumes, according to a new report.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Winnti Group is a threat group with Chinese origins that has been active since at least 2010. The group has heavily targeted the gaming industry, but it has also expanded the scope of its targeting.

tools.name: Winnti
tools.description: Winnti is a trojan typically used by a Chinese advanced persistent threat (APT) group of the same name.

tools.name: PlugX
tools.description: RSA describes PlugX as a RAT (Remote Access Trojan) malware family that is around since 2008 and is used as a backdoor to control the victim's machine fully. Once the device is infected, an attacker can remotely execute several kinds of commands on the affected system.

tools.name: PipeMon
tools.description: In at least one case, the attackers compromised the company’s build orchestration server, allowing them to take control of the victim’s automated build systems. This could have allowed the attackers to trojanize video game executables. With this attack, it would be possible to manipulate in-game currencies for financial gain.

notes.text: Some say 'Blackfly' is an evolution of the Winnti Group, while others say they are separate groups that share tools and techniques. Blackfly has been observed using the same Winnti backdoor as the Winnti Group, as well as other tools and techniques commonly associated with the group.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: APT17 is a China-based threat group that has conducted network intrusions against U.S. government entities, the defense industry, law firms, information technology companies, mining companies, and non-government organizations.

tools.name: BLACKCOFFEE
tools.description: BLACKCOFFEE is malware that has been used by several Chinese groups since at least 2013.

notes.text: This group is a China-based cyber espionage actor believed to be sponsored by the Chinese Ministry of State Security (MSS), specifically the Jinan bureau.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Group 72 is a long standing threat actor group involved in Operation SMN, named Axiom by Novetta. The group is sophisticated, well funded, and possesses an established, defined software development methodology. The group targets high profile organizations with high value intellectual property in the manufacturing, industrial, aerospace, defense, media sectors.

tools.name: BLACKCOFFEE
tools.description: BLACKCOFFEE is malware that has been used by several Chinese groups since at least 2013.

tools.name: gh0st RAT
tools.description: Gh0st RAT (Remote Access Terminal) is a trojan “Remote Access Tool” used on Windows platforms, and has been used to hack into some of the most sensitive computer networks on Earth.

notes.text: Some reporting suggests a degree of overlap between Axiom and Winnti Group but the two groups appear to be distinct based on differences in reporting on TTPs and targeting.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Ke3chang is a threat group attributed to actors operating out of China. Ke3chang has targeted oil, government, diplomatic, military, and NGOs in Central and South America, the Caribbean, Europe, and North America since at least 2010.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post-exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems, enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: ipconfig
tools.description: ipconfig is a Windows utility that can be used to find information about a system's TCP/IP, DNS, DHCP, and adapter configuration.

tools.name: PipeMon
tools.description: Okrum is a Windows backdoor that has been seen in use since December 2016 with strong links to Ke3chang.

description: The Poseidon Group is a long-running team operating on all domains: land, air, and sea. They are dedicated to running targeted attacks campaigns to aggressively collect information from company networks through the use of spear-phishing packaged with embedded, executable elements inside office documents and extensive lateral movement tools.

tools.name: IGT supertool
tools.description: A noteworthy addition to the Poseidon toolkit is the IGT supertool (Information Gathering toolkit), a bulking 15 megabyte executable that orchestrates a series of different information collections steps, exfiltration, and the cleanup of components.

notes.text: The group has a history of using information exfiltrated from victims to blackmail victim companies into contracting the Poseidon Group as a security firm.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: BlackCat (aka ALPHV) is a ransomware family that surfaced in mid-November 2021 and quickly gained notoriety for its sophistication and innovation. Operating a ransomware-as-a-service (RaaS) business model, BlackCat was observed soliciting for affiliates in known cybercrime forums, offering to allow affiliates to leverage the ransomware and keep 80-90% of the ransom payment.

tools.name: BlackCat
tools.description: BlackCat is ransomware written in Rust that has been offered via the Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) model. First observed November 2021, BlackCat has been used to target multiple sectors and organizations in various countries and regions in Africa, the Americas, Asia, Australia, and Europe.

notes.text: Notably, the group uses multiple extortion techniques in some cases, including the siphoning of victim data before ransomware deployment, threats to release data if the ransom is not paid and distributed denial-of-service (DDoS) attacks.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: UNC3944 is a financially motivated threat cluster that has persistently used phone-based social engineering and SMS phishing campaigns (smishing) to obtain credentials to gain and escalate access to victim organizations.

tools.name: BlackCat
tools.description: BlackCat is ransomware written in Rust that has been offered via the Ransomware-as-a-Service (RaaS) model. First observed November 2021, BlackCat has been used to target multiple sectors and organizations in various countries and regions in Africa, the Americas, Asia, Australia, and Europe.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post‑exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, PINs and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems (LSASS memory, SAM, etc.), enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: LaZagne
tools.description: LaZagne is an open-source credential recovery tool that extracts passwords from local applications. It supports modules for browsers, databases, and system components, and has been used by threat actors to gather credentials from compromised systems.

notes.text: Mandiant has already directly observed their targeting broaden beyond telecommunication and business process outsourcer (BPO) companies to a wide range of industries including hospitality, retail, media and entertainment, and financial services.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Earth Freybug is a cyberthreat group that has been active since at least 2012 that focuses on espionage and financially motivated activities. It has been observed to target organizations from various sectors across different countries.

tools.name: UNAPIMON
tools.description: Looking at the behavior of UNAPIMON and how it was used in the attack, we can infer that its primary purpose is to unhook critical API functions in any child process. For environments that implement API monitoring through hooking such as sandboxing systems, UNAPIMON will prevent child processes from being monitored. Thus, this malware can allow any malicious child process to be executed with its behavior undetected.

tools.name: Living off the Land
tools.description: Living-off-the-land tactics mean that attackers are using pre-installed tools to carry out their work. This makes it more difficult for defenders to detect attacks and researchers to identify the attackers behind the campaign. In the attacks we're seeing, there are binaries supplied by the victim's operating system that are normally used for legitimate purposes, but in these cases, are being abused by the attackers.

description: Earth Longzhi is a subgroup of APT41 targeting organizations based in Taiwan, Thailand, the Philippines, and Fiji, and using “stack rumbling” via Image File Execution Options (IFEO), a new denial-of-service (DoS) technique to disable security software.

tools.name: BigpipeLoader
tools.description: Looking at the behavior of UNAPIMON and how it was used in the attack, we can infer that its primary purpose is to unhook critical API functions in any child process. For environments that implement API monitoring through hooking such as sandboxing systems, UNAPIMON will prevent child processes from being monitored. Thus, this malware can allow any malicious child process to be executed with its behavior undetected.

tools.name: Cobalt Strike
tools.description: Cobalt Strike is a commercial, full-featured, remote access tool that bills itself as 'adversary simulation software designed to execute targeted attacks and emulate the post-exploitation actions of advanced threat actors'.

tools.name: CroxLoader
tools.description: This is a custom loader for win.cobalt_strike, used by Earth Longzhi

description: The Central Intelligence Agency is a civilian foreign intelligence service of the federal government of the United States, tasked with gathering, processing, and analyzing national security information from around the world, primarily through the use of human intelligence (HUMINT).

notes.text: The CIA was also one of the parties involved in Operation Olympic Games where Stuxnet was deployed in Iran.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Longhorn has been active since at least 2011. It has used a range of back door Trojans in addition to zero-day vulnerabilities to compromise its targets. Longhorn has infiltrated governments and internationally operating organizations, in addition to targets in the financial, telecoms, energy, aerospace, information technology, education, and natural resources sectors. All of the organizations targeted would be of interest to a nation-state attacker.

tools.name: Black Lambert
tools.description: A malware implant, was found in a 2014 targeted attack against European organizations.

tools.name: Corentry
tools.description: A trojan detected by Symantec as Trojan.Corentry has all the features of the Fluxwire tool contained in the Vault 7 dump. The Fluxwire changelog closely matches the timeline when Symantec detected new features in Corentry samples.

notes.text: Longhorn’s malware appears to be specifically built for espionage-type operations, with detailed system fingerprinting, discovery, and exfiltration capabilities.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: APT42 is an Iranian-sponsored threat group that conducts cyber espionage and surveillance.[1] The group primarily focuses on targets in the Middle East region, but has targeted a variety of industries and countries since at least 2015.

tools.name: NICECURL
tools.description: NICECURL is a VBScript-based backdoor used by APT42 to download additional modules.

tools.name: TAMECAT
tools.description: TAMECAT is a malware that is used by APT42 to execute PowerShell or C# content.

notes.text: APT42 activities have been linked to Magic Hound by other commercial vendors. While there are behavior and software overlaps between Magic Hound and APT42, they appear to be distinct entities and are tracked as separate entities by their originating vendor.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: The activities of the DarkHotel advanced persistent threat (APT) actor came to light in November 2014, when Kaspersky published a report detailing a sophisticated cyberespionage campaign targeting business travelers in the Asia-Pacific region. The group has been around for nearly a decade and some researchers believe its members are Korean speakers.

tools.name: Asruex
tools.description: Asruex infects a system through a shortcut file that has a PowerShell download script, and spreads through removable drives and network drives.

tools.name: Karba
tools.description: This malware is 220Kb in size. It was built as MFC framework application with a lot of extra calls that should have complicated the analysis of the sample. It mimics a GUI desktop application but it does not create any visible windows or dialogs to interact with local users. The Trojan collects data about the system and anti-malware software installed on it, and uploads that data to Darkhotel command and control servers.

notes.text: Some reporting suggests a degree of overlap between DarkHotel and another group named Higaisa, however the two groups appear to be distinct based on differences in reporting on TTPs and targeting.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Higaisa is a threat group suspected to have South Korean origins. Higaisa has targeted government, public, and trade organizations in North Korea; however, they have also carried out attacks in China, Japan, Russia, Poland, and other nations. Higaisa was first disclosed in early 2019 but is assessed to have operated as early as 2009.

tools.name: certutil
tools.description: CertUtil.exe is an admin command line tool intended by Microsoft to be used for manipulating certification authority (CA) data and components. This includes verifying certificates and certificate chains, dumping and displaying CA configuration information and configuring Certificate Services. Attackers can use certutil to replace PowerShell for specific tasks such as downloading a file from a remote URL and encoding and decoding a Base64 obfuscated payload.

tools.name: gh0st RAT
tools.description: Gh0st RAT (Remote Access Terminal) is a trojan “Remote Access Tool” used on Windows platforms, and has been used to hack into some of the most sensitive computer networks on Earth.

tools.name: PlugX
tools.description: RSA describes PlugX as a RAT (Remote Access Trojan) malware family that is around since 2008 and is used as a backdoor to control the victim's machine fully. Once the device is infected, an attacker can remotely execute several kinds of commands on the affected system.

notes.text: Some reporting suggests a degree of overlap between Higaisa and another group named Darkhotel, however the two groups appear to be distinct based on differences in reporting on TTPs and targeting.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: APT33 is a suspected Iranian threat group that has carried out operations since at least 2013. The group has targeted organizations across multiple industries in the United States, Saudi Arabia, and South Korea, with a particular interest in the aviation and energy sectors.

tools.name: AutoIt backdoor
tools.description: AutoIt backdoor is malware that has been used by the actors responsible for the MONSOON campaign. The actors frequently used it in weaponized .pps files exploiting CVE-2014-6352. [1] This malware makes use of the legitimate scripting language for Windows GUI automation with the same name.

tools.name: DEADWOOD
tools.description: DEADWOOD is wiper malware written in C++ using Boost libraries. DEADWOOD was first observed in an unattributed wiping event in Saudi Arabia in 2019, and has since been incorporated into Agrius operations.

tools.name: PlugX
tools.description: RSA describes PlugX as a RAT (Remote Access Trojan) malware family that is around since 2008 and is used as a backdoor to control the victim's machine fully. Once the device is infected, an attacker can remotely execute several kinds of commands on the affected system.

tools.name: Mimikatz
tools.description: Mimikatz is a post‑exploitation tool that extracts plaintext credentials, password hashes, PINs and Kerberos tickets from Windows systems (LSASS memory, SAM, etc.), enabling lateral movement and privilege escalation.

tools.name: LaZagne
tools.description: LaZagne is an open-source credential recovery tool that extracts passwords from local applications. It supports modules for browsers, databases, and system components, and has been used by threat actors to gather credentials from compromised systems.

tools.name: DarkComet
tools.description: DarkComet is a remote access tool (RAT) with features including remote shell, file transfer, keylogging, screen and video capture, and remote process control — commonly used to control compromised hosts and collect sensitive data.

notes.text: APT 33 seems to be closely related to OilRig, APT 34, Helix Kitten, Chrysene since at least 2017.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: APT-C-36 is a suspected South America espionage group that has been active since at least 2018. The group mainly targets Colombian government institutions as well as important corporations in the financial sector, petroleum industry, and professional manufacturing.

tools.name: Imminent Monitor
tools.description: Imminent Monitor was a commodity remote access tool (RAT) offered for sale from 2012 until 2019, when an operation was conducted to take down the Imminent Monitor infrastructure. Various cracked versions and variations of this RAT are still in circulation.

tools.name: AsyncRAT
tools.description: AsyncRAT is a Remote Access Tool (RAT) designed to remotely monitor and control other computers through a secure encrypted connection. It is an open source remote administration tool, however, it could also be used maliciously because it provides functionality such as keylogger, remote desktop control, and many other functions that may cause harm to the victim’s computer.

notes.text: Till this moment, 360 Threat Intelligence Center captured 29 bait documents, 62 Trojan samples and multiple related malicious domains in total. Attackers are targeting Windows platform and aiming at government institutions as well as big companies in Colombia.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Cisco Talos and other security researchers have recently reported on a series of malicious campaigns targeting the aviation industry. These reports mainly center around the crypter that hides the usage of commodity malicious remote access tools.

tools.name: AsyncRAT
tools.description: AsyncRAT is a Remote Access Tool (RAT) designed to remotely monitor and control other computers through a secure encrypted connection. It is an open source remote administration tool, however, it could also be used maliciously because it provides functionality such as keylogger, remote desktop control, and many other functions that may cause harm to the victim’s computer.

tools.name: CyberGate RAT
tools.description: According to Subex Secure, CyberGate is a Remote Access Trojan (RAT) that allows an attacker to gain unauthorized access to the victim’s system. Attackers can remotely connect to the compromised system from anywhere around the world.

tools.name: njRAT
tools.description: njRAT is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first observed in 2012. It has been used by threat actors in the Middle East.

description: The Syrian Electronic Army uses spam, website defacement, malware, phishing and denial of service attacks against political opposition groups, Western news agencies, human rights groups and seemingly neutral websites for Syrian conflicts.

tools.name: AndoServer
tools.description: AndoServer malware, which can capture GPS data, steal call logs and text messages, launch other apps, take screenshots and record audio, among other functions.

tools.name: SandroRAT
tools.description: A novel functionality of this threat is its ability to access the encrypted Whatsapp chats (available in the path /WhatsApp/Databases/msgstore.db.crypt5 on the SD card) and obtain the unique encryption key using the Google email account of the device to get the chats in plain text and store them in the file waddb.sr. Also has normal functionality found in other Android RATs

tools.name: SLRat
tools.description: SLRat appears to have gained popularity since its developer first publicized it in May 2016, advertising it as 'the Best and Free android remote admin tool'

description: Goldmouse (APT-C-27), also known as Golden Rat, is a Syria-linked subgroup of the Syrian Electronic Army (SEA) active since 2014. The group conducts cyber espionage and information theft, primarily targeting the Middle East using tools like GoldenRAT, njRAT, and exploiting vulnerabilities such as WinRAR CVE-2018-20250.

tools.name: njRAT
tools.description: njRAT is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first observed in 2012. It has been used by threat actors in the Middle East.

tools.name: GoldenRAT
tools.description: After analysing the backdoor script, as mentioned earlier, we found that this is a classic backdoor that has been circulating on the network for a long time. Features include getting system information and uploading, setting up scheduled tasks, downloading files, executing shell commands, deleting files, ending processes, traversing file drivers and processes, and more.

notes.text: Primary Targets: Focused on government, military, and political entities in the Middle East, often linked to groups opposing the Assad regime.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda

description: Pat Bear (APT-C-37 / Racquet Bear) is a Syria-linked subgroup of the Syrian Electronic Army active since 2015, conducting targeted espionage and surveillance—often via watering-hole sites and malicious mobile/desktop RATs (DroidJack, H-Worm, njRAT, SpyNote)—with campaigns focused on defense and regional actors including ISIS, Egypt, and Israel.

tools.name: njRAT
tools.description: njRAT is a remote access tool (RAT) that was first observed in 2012. It has been used by threat actors in the Middle East.

tools.name: DroidJack
tools.description: DroidJack is an Android remote access tool that has been observed posing as legitimate applications including the Super Mario Run and Pokemon GO games.

tools.name: H-Worm
tools.description: H-worm is a VBS (Visual Basic Script) based RAT written by an individual going by the name Houdini. We believe the author is based in Algeria and has connections to njq8, the author of njw0rm and njRAT/LV through means of a shared or common code base.

notes.text: Targeted espionage and surveillance (information theft) rather than financially motivated crime.
notes.author: Analyst Lucas Oda
